div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

div.head: Legislative Council.
div.p: The Legislative Council will meet in Cairo on the 1st December.

div.head: Ministry of Justice.
div.p: The Ministry of Justice, in its Budget for 1907, has provided for seven new judgeships of various degrees.

div.head: Minieh Agricultural Show.
div.p: "Al Minbar" states that H.H. the Khedive will probably not visit the Agricultural Show at Minieh.

div.head: Al Azhar.
div.p: The new scholastic year of Al A-zhar University begins on the 27th ins, when the religions studies will be resumed at that institution.

div.head: Plague Credit.
div.p: The Council of Ministers has passed the opening of a credit of L E. 10.000 fur the Public Health Department to cover the cost of prophylactic measures to combat the plague.

div.head: Fatal Accident.
div.p: A native mason fell from a building in course of construction in. the Attarin quarter yesterday and received serious injuries, to which he succumbed shortly afterwards in the Government Hospital.

div.head: Wife Murderer Sentenced. |
div.p: The Attarin Criminal Court has sentenced Mohamad Mustafa, a native of Alexandria, to penal servitude for life, for the murder of his wife in a public bath, in September last, as related in our columns.

div.head: Yeung Greek's Suicide.
div.p: A young Greek committed suicide yesterday by hanging himself with a rope which he bad fastened to a wooden fence on the banks of the Farkba Canal, Moharrem Bey. A piece of paper was found in deceased's pocket in which he stated that he had taken his life in a fit of despair.

div.head: Trial of Slave Dealer.
div.p: The Ashabab tribe, who are notorious slave dealers, lately attacked a patrol near Cape Benas, in the Red Sea. The raiders were overcome, and on the 8*h inst., at Assouan, their, leader, Mohamed Nosseir, was sentenced to, fifteen years' bard labour. On December 28, I 1905, they sold twelve slaves to the Hedjsz.

div.head: Egyptian State Domain Bonds.
div.p: Messrs N. M. Rnthwlrld and 8ons announce that Egyptian State Domain Mortgage bonds to the amount of £11,2 20 nominal capital have been drawn for payment at par on December 1st. The drawing consists ot all bonds (not previously cancelled by the operation of the sinking fond) comprised in the series of numbers advertised.

div.head: Talodi Campaign.
div.p: The names of El Kaimakam A.J.B. Percival Bey, D.8.O., Officer Commanding, Camel Corps, B1 Kaimakam H.M. Hutchinson Bey, D.S.O., Officer Commanding, 12th Sudanese^ and Depaty Inspector J. W. Sagar, Sudan Government, should have been added to the list of officers whose names were forwarded to the Khedive in connection with the operations at Talodi.

div.head: P 0. Savings Bank Department
div.p: In order to encourage thrift in children and to save them the inconvenience of going to the Post Office each time they wish to make a deposit in the Savings Bank, a postal official will be detailed to visit all schools in Alexandria and Cairo, having a minimum of 20 depositors, twice aweek in order to receive deposits. This service will take effect from the 1st December next.
International Wrestling Championship.

A grand international wrestling championship has been organized by the Parisian sporting journal, the "Auto," and will be challenged for here shortly. The prize ia 5,000 francs. The champions are Paul Pons, who has won the Golden Belt; Shackmann, the ''Terrible German" Ahmed Ali, the Egyptian, who weighs 115 kilos, and stands l.SO metres in his stockings. All desirous of entering should apply to Mr. L. Luason, of the "Auto," Hotel Borel.

div.head: Wesleyan Methodism in Cairo.
div.p: For 21 years the Rev. Wm. Jackson, Chaplain to the Wesleyan troops in Cairo, has held a voluntary service in a room attached to his own residence. This meeting has been a religious centre not only to the military and civilians resident in Cairo, but to many of our annual visitors. An effort is now being made to extend the influence of this Sunday evening service, and to this end the German Hall in Sharia el Manakh (entrance opposite the Eastern Telegraph Company's office) has been secured. Arrangements have been made for local speakers, and with the additional help of ministers and others who may be visiting Cairo, it is confidently expected that these meetings will prove highly successful. We are able to state for the information of our readers that further particulars may be obtained on application to Mr. Walter Turnbull, of Helouan.

div.head: Alexandria's New Quay
div.p: This Morning's Auction

Average prices were realized this morning at the third public auction of the Alexandria Municipality's new quay estate. The sales began at 10 o'clock in the hall of the Municipal Delegation. It was remarked that in spite of the fact that these sales have been widely advertised and the chance of the land advancing in price on this unique site is almost assured, yet the attendance was extraordinarily sparse, only a handful of intending purchasers putting in an appearance—about ten in all. The following prices were realized

div.head:
Excelsior Hotels CO.
MAY SELL THEIR NEW SITE.
div.p: It is reported that the Excelsior Hotels Company are considering an offer for the purchase of their land opposite the Standard building, on which they have already commenced operations for their new hotel The price mentioned is L.E. 37 per metre.

div.head: Important Sale of Cairo Property.
div.p: We are informed that Messrs. Snares have sold their block of buildings known as the Eastern Telegraph Block, to Khilil BeyChahine and M. Parissis Belienis for L.E. 52 per metre. Tbe-e gentlemen have since received an offer for the repurchase of the property from other parties for L.E. 65 per metre.

div.head: ABOUKIR COMPANY.
div.p: There has been a phenomenal demand at Alexandria for the Aboukir company's new issue, which dosed this morning on the Bourse at £2 8s. The shares are quite worth £3 in view of the fact that the company holds the only large area of unsold first-class agricultural land within twenty miles of Alexandria. The company have still 11,OOO feddans to dispose of. Of the previously sold land the company have about £180,000 to encash, over a shortnumber of years, every piastre of which is sure to come in. Of this sum no less than £100.000 is profit available for dividends, and with that and £ rapidly increasing, rent roll dividends of a good size are provided for years to come.

div.head: ANGLO EGYPTIAN BANK.
div.p: The report of the Anglo Egyptian Bank tor the year to August 31 shows an increase of as much as £15,446 in gross profits, earned at an addition of £10,661 to the expenses. To the net gain of £14,785 has to be added a bought-in balance larger by £21 000; so that, in all, £35,785 more was available for distribution or ''otherwise. To reserve £50,000 is allotted and to pension reserve £I0,0T0, against nothing and £3'\000 a year ago ; the dividend is raised from 12 to 15 percent., requiring £12,500 additional; the contribution ; to staff provident fund is increased by £285, ; to make the forward balance an even sum of ; £(29,000, or £7,000 less than that of a year ago. Notwithstanding the signs of expanding business, the advances outstanding at August 31 have diminished from £4,713,360 to £4,022,660, and the bills receivable from £1,422,530 to £1,086,070. while the cash holdings have risen from £711,413 to £948,13'. Tin reserve now exceeds the paid-up capital by £50,0C0.

div.head: COTTON MILLS ON FIRE.
div.p: Fire broke out yesterday afternoon in the cotton mills at Karmous, and the flames extended to the goods store, destroying 150 ran tars (f cotton, valued at L E. 300. The fire, which is said to be due to the overbeating of the machinery, was extinguished by the Fire Brigade after a good deal of trouble.

div.head: M SAINT SAENS' FAREWELL.
div.p: M. Camille Saint-Sauna, returning to New from Chicago. where he received an enthusiastic and affectionate welcome, told a "New York Herald" reporter that the American tour would end his career as a pianist. He:—"I am happy to make my farewell in a contry that is new and wonderfully interesting to me."

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT:
div.p: THE DENSHAWI "DOSSIER."

In the House of Commons liet Thoriday, Mr. Dillon asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether 'bis attention had been drawn to the statement that the transla tion of the documents connected with the Dershawi case was conducted ander the supervision of Judge Bond ; and, if this statement be correct, whether he would see that a trade. lation conducted under the supervision or some independent and impartial person, and not under the supervision of one of the members of the special tribunal,, whose action was to be considered by the House, was laid before Parliament.

Sir E. Grey said he did not know that the document was gopervised by Judge Bond. If it was so he would regard it as a guarantee of Accuracy, for he had every confidence in his independence. He saw no reason to doubt the accuracy of the translation.
EXPLOSIVES IN EGYPT.

Sir E. Grey informed Dr. Ratherford that he would bok for information as to whether any regulations were in force in Egypt as, to the landing at Egyptian ports, storage, and transport by rail, river, or canal, of explosives.

div.head: THE KUBDIVE'S DEPARTURE.
div.p: In view of the official departure of H.H. the Khedive for Cairo on Saturday next at 78 m., the Alexandria Guuvernorat has issued the following order :

Carriages will not be allowed to pass through the streets on his Highness's route from Raa. el Tin Palace to Moharrem Bey station at the following hours: Castoms-street, 7 a.m.; Frank-street, 7.10; Mohamed-Aly-square, 7.15; and Attarin, 7.15. Carriages going to the station will be stopped only on the pageage of the Khadivial procestion. Tae carriages of those specially invited to the station should enter the station-yard from the door opposito Mahallet-Masr-street. .
The Khedive will arrive at Cairo station from Aloxandria at 11.30 a.m. and will proceed direct to Abdeen Palace.
H.H. the Khedivah will leave Montazah the same day at 7.40 8.m., arriving at Koabbeh Palace at 12.10 p.m.

div.head: THE HOLY CARPET.
div.p: The Ministry of War is preparing the Mabmal for the forthcoming pilgrimnge. The Holy Carpet will be guarded this year by a detachment of the 3rd Battalion, a body of mounted troops, and a battery of artillery.
Dr. Hassan Eff. Kamel, of the Medical Corps, has been selected to accompany the Mabmal to Mecca.

div.head: PROVINCIAL APPOINTMENTS. We understand that Ismail Bey Sidky, head of the administrative service and Contentieux of the Manicipality of Alexandria, Hassan Boy Maz'oum, secretary to the Financial Adviser, and Mohamed Bey Mahmoud, son of the President of the Legislative Council, have been appointed to important posts in the provincial Administration
PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT.
div.p: The Public Works Department has decided to restore the post of director general of State Towns and Buildings, rendered vacant by the promotion of Mr. Perry to be Under-Secretary of State, and has designated tberefor Mr. Richmond inspector of Towns and Buildings, and member of the Higher Municipal Commission. Mr. Richmond is also a member of the committee which examines all schemes for Government works; Lord Edward Cecil and Mr. Perry being aleo members of the same committee.

div.head: CAIRO TRAMWAYS.
div.p: We are in a position to announce the gatis. factory conolagion of the negotiations between the Public WorkDepartment and the Cairo Tramway Company relative to laying the new lines over Ghizeh Bridge, and that work to that end will begin at once so as to have the extension ready for the formal opening of the bridge in February next.

When Boulac Bridge is built, & second line of tramway will join the first at Ghizeh, crossing Ghezireh and going round the property of Prince Hassein Pasha Kamel, thus doing away with that section of the Pyramids line between Ghczireh and Ghizeh.

div.p: Mustapha Pasha Fahmy has arrived from Simbellawein at Damietts, where he was visited at the Gouvernorat by the Consoler Corpg and a large number of native notables and olema. The Prime Minister returns to Alexandria this evening

div.head:
Germany and Egypt
ATTITUDE NOT UNFRIENDLY.
div.p: GREAT BRITAIN'S POSITION ACKNOWLEDGED.

Prince von Bulow, the German Chancellor, delivered an important speech in the Reichstag last week in reply to an interpellation on Germany's foreign policy, in which he referred at considerable length to the desire of Germany for friendly relations with her neighbors. The tone of the speech throughout was conciliatory, and the Chancellor's references to Great Britain were particularly felicitous. "No really profound political differences," said the Chancellor,-"exist between. Great Britain and Germany. There have been moments of discord between the two peoples, for which, as is usual in life, both parties were about equally to blame. There have, however, been no hostile acta. In intellectual matters, in the arts and sciences, the two countries are close to one another. In the same way they are economically interdependent. Economic competition and rivalry need not kindle any political antagonism, still leas a war. Germany and Bogland are good customers to each other; indeed, such good customers that they both; have every reason to retain each other's custom. (' Hear, hear," from the Left.) For this reason alone all sensible people should do their utmost to remove misunderstandings and to foster mutual understanding."

Prince Bulow went on to refer to the visit of German civic representatives and journalists to Great Britain, and said that he hoped that good would ensue from both visits. Ha could confirm the remark that the enthusiasm manifested at one time in Germany for the Boers did not spring from hatred of England. Continuing, Prince Bulow said :

''We acknowledge, and without reservation, the position which Great Britain has long since made for herself in the world. That that is no figure of speech is proved by our attitude in the Egyptian question. Prince Bismarck used to say, 'In Servia, we are Austrian ; in Bulgaria, Russian ; in Egypt, British.' Since Prince Bismarck's day also we have put no stone in the way of Great Britain in Egypt, not even when we had a formal right to do so. I refer to the occasion of the issue of the Khedival Decree of 1904, to which we assented without question. The establishment of friendly and confidential relations between Great Britain and Germany demands time and patience, for a long period o£ misunderstandings lies behind us The vital interests of great nations must stand high above personal differences and susceptibilities. ("Hear, hear," of the Left.)
Disagreements Between Rulers.

"Too much weight has been attributed to alleged personal disagreements between the rulers of Great Britain and Germany. Neither King Edward nor the Emperor will allow personal susceptibilities to exercise influence when material considerations are at stake. The Kronberg meeting strengthened the good personal relations between them."

Referring to the attitude of Italy at the Morocco Conference, the Imperial Chancellor said : "We bad no complaint to mak9. Italy was in) a difficult position. There existed between her and France certain agreements regarding Morocco, about which we know that they were not in conflict with the Triple Alliance. The Triple Alliance has not yet had a chance of being put to a practical teat. This possibility has, however, been mainly spared it just because it existed and because a central European league was actually in being. That has substantially contributed to averting the chief danger to European peace. This proves that the Triple Alliance still has important advantages as compared with other conceivable combinations. The Triple Alliance has the additional advantage of making conflicts between the three allied States out of the question."

div.head: RAISING OF ASSOUAN DAM.
div.p: Sir Benjamin Baker will visit Assouan in a short time to study whether it will be possible to raise the dam. Sir Benjamin's views will be communicated to the Egyptian Government

div.head: NAVAL NOTES.
div.p: 8oer, Wednesday.
H M.S. sloop Merlin arrived at Suez yesterday from Port Said, and is now moored in the North Basin at Port Ibrahim.
The French first class armoured cruisers, the Monteaum, Gueydon, and Dupetit Thouars, arrived at Suez this morning from the Far East, and entered the Canal at noon for Port Said.

div.head: Jane Hading In Cairo
div.p: "LE DEMI MONDE"
(From our Theatrical Correspondent.)

By a crowning mercy no other Dumas fils play will be performed by Mme Hading. The "Demi Monde" was most trying. Five acts full of platitudes, complications, plots, and counterplot, completed, or rather strangled, at last by a weird nightmare - denouement which seemed to give the lie to all the piece, and all the note aimed at by the heroine. M. Arnaui is certainly very good: be has that quality - esprit—hardly wit so much as exact appreciation of the value of his words and gestures. He did not exaggerate, and he was not theatrical. It would have been s i easy to spoil Olivier de Palin, as easy as to mar Raymond de Nanjao, and I cannot say that M. Hanterive was far off that achievement He was stiff and over-excitable, too well drilled often. Mme Sureaa was good, in that her part suited her: a touch of the adventuress without depth, or much scruple, and a certain noisiness, wore evidently quite in place And Madame Hading herself 7 Again wonderful', holding attention, absolutely convincing. and, so it seemed to me at last, transforming a most; wayward and inconsistent part into very great and splendid unity. The Baronne D'Ange is of, course, a woman with a past. She fights it down resolutely. All her behavior, her schemes, her love, fear, her most bitter trusting confession of all, her prayers and hopes—all useless, and far worse all marred by that volte face at the end. Palin has won his point, and defeated her. Nanjao. always only too ready to believe ill has cast her off and is feeling virtuous and almost great! And then she is made to return suddenly to some old phase of real unscrupulousness, to laugh in their faces, and brandish the title deeds, which she had not returned after all, in their faces. What could be more unconvincing? It made me think (but this is. fearful heresy—of the faggot eveu!) of, say, a Sohumanne que setting of—well, of any great love opera, "Toscs" perhaps, though the story is so wholly different-bat "Tosoa" has the same emotion and consistent love. I could not help imagining this play as an altered version of "Tosca" in its fire and sorrow, killed and crushed at the end by a jarring denunciation as to morality in general. I do not say Schamann would jar in that way, bat I feel sure that the didactic intellectual mode, mingled with sentiment and emotion, and indeed the calm (even dullness now and again) of the opening acts, is Damas and Schumann, and not reality,—a professor trying to solve a "passionel" case. One could write pages on Jane Hading in the part, bat is it not enough to say that she seemed to transform the whole play, and showed yet another side and interpretation of herself, greater surely than the part she had to interpret?

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p: Princess Norjian left for Constantinople by the S.S. Osmanieh yesterday.

Lady Wingate, accompanied by Lewa Bernard Pasha Financial Secretary of the Sudan Government, leaves Cairo on the 26th inst. for Khartonm. Her ladyship will travel by rail to Lnxor, proceeding thence to Shellal by water.
Sir William Garstin left for the Sudan last night. We understand that the Adviser will be absent for about a month.
Yaconb Pasha Artin, late Under Secretary of State for Public Instruction, has had conferred on him by the Khedive the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Osmanieh.

Lady Ulrica Baring, who arrived at Cairo on Monday, is staying at the British Agency as the guest of the Earl and Countess of Cromer. Lady Ulrica is the youngest of the four lovely daughters of the Earl and Countess of Fever- sham. Her sisters are Lady Helen Vincent, Lady Cynthia Graham, and the late Duchess of Leinster, ladies all lamed for their beauty.

Lady Ulrica has the deep blue eyes and abundant dark hair which distinguished the late Duchess of Leiuster. At one of the balls given by the officers of the 10th Hussars at York the evening was opened with a cotillon danced by what were generally considered to be the four most beautiful women in England, and the quartette include! Lady Ulrica's three sisters. Bat for the fact that Lady Ulrica was still pursuing her studies she would have been included in the cotillon.

Lady Ulrica studied at Newnham College for a considerable time. With a mind inclined towards serious work she afterwards took up hospital nursing, and went through a comprehensive training, including work in the East End. Her marriage to Colonel the Hon. Everard Baring took place last autumn. Colonel Baring, who was Military Secretary to Lord Curzon in India and served in the Sudan and in South Africa, comes of the same family as Lord Cromer.

M. and Mme. Charles de Zogheb last Friday evening entertained a brilliant dinner party at their Dew mansion in the Rue de Faisanderie, Paris. Among those present were : Mme John Balli, Mme. Manrice Ejhrassi, M. and Mme Andr6 de Gouroay, M. Alioti, Comte de Zogheb, M. Nicolopnlo, M. M chel Sinadino, Comte Georges de Monteeqaioa. The dinner was followed by bridge.

Baron de Kneel Bey, late general manager of the Egyptian Trust and Investment, Limited, has just severed his connection with that company, and has handed over all the assets to the Building Lands of Egypt. He is not leaving Egypt, and we understand that the Baron has been approached with a view to securing his services for some other local companies.

We regret to announce the death of Mr. Amabile Cumbo, late Municipal Councilor of Alexandria. The deceased is said to have left £200,000. He only took up his permanent residence in Italy this year, when he assumed a baronial prefix. The baron, we hear, died of galloping consumption. He recently purchased a magnificent palace in Rome.
Mr. James Duckworth, the Liberal member for Stockport, has been advised by his doctors to winter abroad in the interests of his health. He is coming to Egypt, and will possibly visit Khartoam.
Miss Grace Bell, daughter of Mr. Charles J. Bell, has left Washington for London, where she is to meet a party of English friends and with them go to Bombay. She will spend the winter in Egypt.
Mr. J. J. Netheray and his brother, with their families, have left Takoma Park for New York, en route to Egypt.
The engagement is announced of M. Andre de Magnin and Mile Sophie Ralli, daughter of Mme Antoine Ralli.
Said Bey Shukair, chef des bureaux of the Sudan Financial Department, leaves Cairo on the 28th inst. for Khartoum, to join Bernard Pasha.
Dr. Ibrahim Eff. Fahmi has been appointed physician to Kasr el-Aini Hospital, in place of Dr. Girgis El-Dabaa, who has been transferred to the Public Health Department.

div.head: SOCIETE GENERALE DE PRESSAGE ET DE DEPOTS.
div.p: EXERCICE 1905-1906.
L'assemblée générale de la Société de Pres ange et de Dépôts s'est tenue le 29 écoulé au siège social, Alexandrie. Voici le rapport da Conseil d'administration qui a été la devant l'assemblée:-
Nous avons l'honneur de vous rendre compte de notre gestion pour l'Exercice 1905-1906.
Le bénéfice net des comptes clôturés au 31 Août 1906, s'élève à P.T. 3.284 763, 5/10, et oe, après amortissement complet du coût des hangars des Dattiers et de la cheminés presse ex-Choremi.
Da chef de cet amortissement la dédaction 'élève à P.T. 187.726, 2/10.

Bien qu'inférieur à oelai da dernier Exercice et produit par an pressage de Balles 508.623, dépassant le précédent de 1.991 Baller, ce bénéfice est néanmoins normal étant donnée l'augmentation du coût de la main-d'œuvre dans toutes les branches de nos services.

Nous avons ea à sabir, comme d'ailleurs toutes les Sociétés Industrielles, les conséquences de l'énorme plus-value de tout ce qui constitue le nécessaire et l'indispensable à la vie de DOS ouvriers et de notre personnel en général; nous avons dû accueillir des demandes absolament fondées d'augmentation de salaire de la part de nos presseurs, de nos ouvriers, de nos portafaix, de nos charretiers, ainsi que de tous ceux qui contribuent à l'exploitation de notre industrie. Néanmoins, nous sommes en mesure, après règlement de toutes charges statutaires, de vous proposer la distribution de 10% pour intérêts et dividende et la rétrocession à Messieurs les Presseurs de P.T.157.493, - ce qui représente P.T. 41. par 1.000 Cantars pressés.
Ces deux prélèvements effectuér, Dons aurons un solde disponible de P.T. 319.612.

Nous référant à votre décision, prise lors de la dernière Assemblée Générale, d'employer en rachats d'Obligations tout excédent dépas sant le 10% de Dividende, votre Conseil, en présence de la nouvelle situation créée à votre Société, oroit devoir vous laisser le soin de décider à nouveau sur l'emploi de ce montant.

Si ces propositions sont adoptées, Messieurs, la part vous revenant pour l'Exercice 1905-1906 Bera de £2 par Action. Un dividende intérimaire de £0.12/- par Action ayant été payé le ler Mars dernier le solde soit £1.8/ par Action sera mis à votre disposition à partir du 5 Novembre prochain.

L'incendie d'une partie de la presse ex-Choremi a été réglé par les Compagnies d'Assurances dans des conditions satisfaisantes et nons n'aurons à subir tout au plus qu'an léger retard dans la reprise régulière du travail, retard qui d'ailleurs sera vits compensé par le surplus de production que nous devrons à l'installation d'une nouvelle et puissante presse. Les 3 Administrateurs sortant cette annéa Bont: Messieurs C. de Tachadi, Ed. Tschopp et W. F. Peel.-I's sont rééligibles.
Vous aurez encore, Messieurs, a élire les Censeurs pour l'Exercice 1906-1907 et à fixer le montant de lear allocation.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Auiourd'hui à midi et demie.)

La tenue de notre marché est exceptionnellement ferme sur toute la ligne; beaucoup de valeurs sont en hausse et l'animation est presque générale; les transactions portent spécialement sur la National Bank, la Daïra, la Cassa di Sconto, la Delta Land, les Estates, et le Comptoir.

En Union Foncière il y a une demande très active qui pousse le cours à 6 5/8 acheteurs, mais, par suite de l'absence de vendeurs, les affaires sont clairsemées. La Daïra s'avance de 16 7/8 17 5/16, la Delta Land de 4 1/16 à 4 3/16, la Nile Land de 17 à 17 1/4, lea Estates de 2 8/16 à 27/32 et l'Urbaine de 6 7/16 à 6 16/32. La Béhéra est stationnaire à 41. De 27 5/16 la National Bank monte à 27 8/2, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 885 à 336 1/2, la Cassa di Sconto de 238 et 233 à 241 1/2 et 286 1/2, la Banque d'Athènes de 146 1/2 à 147 1/4, la Land Bank de 9 à 9 1/82, le Com ptoir de 7 at 6 3/4 à 7 3/16 et 6 15/16 l'action et de 50 1/2 à 58 la part de fondateur, et la Banque d'Orient de 138 1/2 à 134. L'Agricole réactionne légèrement de 9 25/32 à 9 3/4.

La Privilégiée Bière d'Alexandrie te raffermit 215, tandis que la Dividende Bière da Caire Hookit de 78 à 77. La Salt and Soda s'avance de 23/9 à 24, l'Anglo-American Nile de 5 3/4 à 6 18/16, les Nangovich de 18 5/16 à 18 7/16, et l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 36 & 37/6.
Tout le reste de la cote est soutena.

div.p: In view of proposed tunnelling near St. Paul's Cathedral the architect has made the startling discovery that the south west tower has started subsiding, and at present has a list of thirteen inches. (Reuter)

div.head:
Big Fire At Toulon
Great Damage to Shipyards.

div.p: A great fire is raging in the private shipyards here. The damage is already estimated at 2,000,000 francs. The warships in course of construction were saved with the greatest difficulty.
Later.
The fire was extinguished before any warships were injured. It is believed to have started in an enormous stack of timber. (R.)
A fire at the La Seyne dockyards has caused damage to the extent of two millions of francs.
(Havas)

div.head:
Russia and Japan
THE COMMERCIAL TREATY.

div.p: The Russo Japanese conference here is making progress with the commercial treaty. The articles regarding the most favoured nation have been agreed to reciprocally.
(Reuter)

div.head:
French Inventories.
ATTACK ON M. CLEMENCEAU.

div.p: M. Gaudin de Villaine, Conservative, denounced M. Clemenceau in the Senate yesterday for resuming the inventories of the church property. Ha regretted that the Catholics had Dot the courage to resist persecution by the Russian terrorist methods. M. Clemenceau justified the inventories by the necessity for the transfer of the church property by the 12th December. The 8enate voted confidence in him by 213 votes to 32. (Router)
The inventories of the churches are proceeding without incident. (Havas)

Details of the Peary Expedition show that the failure to reach even a higher latitude was due to a storm opening a great lane of water behind it and cutting off the possibility of support from relief parties. Consequently Commander Peary made an independent dash, but when, on the 21st April, he reached 87°6' degrees and provisions were almost exhausted, he decided to return after planting flags high up on an ice pinnacle. (Feuter)

div.head:
S.S. Coronation Ashore.
CARGO FROM ALEXANDRIA.

div.p: The British steamer Coronation, from Alexandria, has been stranded on the Dragonera reef and is in a bad position. (F'euter)
The warships Pelayo and Molina have arrived. The British squadron is expected. (Havas)
The Emperor has arrived. (Havas)

div.head: Meterology of the Nile Valley.*
div.p: (Continued)

The main flood water of the Nile is brought down By the Blue Nile and the Athara from the Abyssinian plateau. The rainfall occurs between June and September, and is immediately discharged down the hills into the valleys, the greatest portion down the Blue Nile, which joins the White Nile (there forming the Nile) at Khartoum. The maximum flood of the Blue Nile is about 12,500 cubic metres, and of the Atbara 5,000 cubic meters per second.

The Nile flood proper is hence doe solely to rainfall in the Abyssinian and adjacent Sudan area. It commences in Jane, and reaches its maximum about the end of August or beginning of September. The maximum height of the Nile flood, or the total discharge during the flood period, may hence be accepted as a measure of the total rainfall over that area, j opt as the variations of the Victoria and Albert Lakes represent the seasonal variations of the rainfall in their catchment areas.

The Nile below the junction of the Atbara (lat. 18° N to lat. 34° N.) receives no affluents, and flows in a comparatively narrow valley, over which the flood waters, with their rich alluvial contents, are distributed by means of a vast system of canals.

The Nile basin may hence be divided into three areas or regions, not differing greatly in breadth from south to north. The most southerly is the equatorial lake belt between lat. 6° S and 5° N., an intermediate region between lat. 5° N. and lat 18° N. includes the Sudan and Abyssinia, and the northerly region com-prises the lower Nile basin from lat. 18° N. to the Mediterranean in lat. 34° N. The low river supply (January to May) is chiefly due to discharge from the equatorial Uke area, and the summer flood supply to discharge from the Abyssinian region.
The following gives a sketch of the more important features of the meteorology of the Nile basin, based on the important information and data of Captain Lyons's monograph.

Temperature is remarkably uniform in the equatorial lake region. Thus at Entebbe, on the north shore of the Victoria Nyanza, it ranges only between a mean of 72° 7 in January and 70° in July. In the Nile basin north of about lat. 5° N. temperature is lowest in January, and attains its maximum in May in the southern half of the valley south of Khartonm, and in July in Nubia and Egypt. The annual range of temperature increases northwards from the equatorial belt to northern Egypt. The greater part of the Nile basin is within the tropics, and is throughout the whole year characterized by high temperature. That portion of it between lit. 15" N. and lat. 18° N. (in which are the meteorological stations of Khartoum, Berber, and Dongola) is the hottest and driest area in the Nile basin. It has an elevation of about 1200 foot. To the south is the comparatively damp and cooler region of the Bahr-el Ghazal, the Albert Nile, and the lake plateau, whilst to the north the valley descends slowly to the relatively cool Mediterranean coast. This —the Sudan hot area—is one of the hottest regions in the world.

The data show that at the hottest period, from May to September, the high temperature conditions are as intense in the Sudan hot area as in Upper Sind, and are more prolonged and persistent. This hot area plays a very important part in the meteorology of the Nile basin. It is throughout the whole year much hotter than Lower Egypt. The difference between the mean day temperature at Berber and Alexandria increases from 8° in January to 16° in April and May. it thence diminishes under the influence of the monsoon rainfall in the Sudan region to 8° in August, and increases to a second maximum (12°) in November. It is undoubtedly due to the presence of this permanent hot area in the central Nile basin that northerly winds prevail almost continuously in the northern half of the basin (i.e. north of Eerber). The Massawa data also indicate that the hottest portion of the Red sea is from 10° to 16° cooler during the day hours from*March to October than the land area to the west. As the width of the Red Sea in lat. 15° to 20° N. is about 300 miles, it is evident that the presence of this relatively cool area will modify considerably the air movement and pressure distribution in the adjacent land areas, more especially the Sudan comparatively low- lying urea. ("Nature".)
'•The Physiography of the River Nile and its Basin," By Captain H. G. Lyons, K. K., Director General, Egyptian Survey Department.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market.

Money is gradually ceasing to be the dominant factor it has been for so many anxious month". The barometer points to change, and while the hand fluctuates in a spasmodic manner, there are good grounds for believing that it is slowly making for "fair" if not "set fair." True the same can hardly be said for the state of the barometer in New York, where extreme fluctuations and occasional squeezes are still probable, but this often happens without any serious effect upon the money position on this side. There is no talk of farther gold exports to that quarter, and the endeavor to float their New York financial bills here are not meeting with success.

Discounts, however, are very firm. Day to day money realises 5½ to 6 per cent., and 6 to 6½ per cent. for 3 months and longer. The Bank position is further improved, the reserve being about £1 000,000 higher, being over 40¼ per cent., which, however, is considerably below last year, when it was 42 per cent. The tempting deposit rate of 4 to 4½ per cent, which the Banks and Discount Houses are allowing most bring in large amounts of idle capital and is not likely to last very long. The improved position is reflected in the market for first class securities although the return from these is considerably less than is obtain able in the market for loans, and no considerable rise can take place in Consols until money is very much cheaper.
The Stock Markets.

The tone generally in the stock markets is now more favourable, and investors are coming forward well. In nearly all sections cheerfulness is predominant, and even .gilt- edged securities, which have for some time been under the influence of the money situation, now display a much better tendency. For this latter satisfactory state of things, the considerable improvement in the condition of the money market is largely responsible.

The details connected with the settlement occupied attention at the beginning of the week, but when this was safely out of the way a comparatively active business commenced in most sections, and it is permissible to hope that this has been no spasmodic fit of excitement, but a steady and genuine revival. The prospects for the future of stock and share dealings are excellent, and it seems probable that the forecast we gave of a return of prosperity when the money situation improved will be fully realised. This is a consummation which will be gratefuly welcomed by brokers, who have become well nigh disheartened by the continuance of listless markets and lack of business.
Egyptian shares, it is pleasing to Dote, have again been much in evidence, and we may safely predict that this season will see greater activity in this section than has previously been known.
Consols.

The dearness of money had depressed the gilt edged section daring the greater part of the week, and op to yesterday Consols had exhibited a continued tendency to sag. The excellent Bank return showing an addition to the reserve of nearly a million brought a more cheerful tone, and the quotation for the premier security was marked slightly higher at the close. The price to-night for cash is 86 5/8 Foreign Bonds.

In the international market the demand for Japanese Four-and a-half per cents, has been renewed, and yesterday the stock gained a further 3/8 at 95½. Russian bonds have been quiet, following last week's reaction, but they now display a tendency to harden, the Fours being better at 77 and the scrip of the Fives at 5¾ discount.
Home Balls.

Home railway shares have been a very good market throughout, the favourable settlement of the Clyde dispute having exercised an invigorating influence. Even the publication of a rather poor batch of traffic returns failed to check the advance. There has been substantial investment buying of the heavy stocks, and Lancashire and Yorkshire were yesterday freely absorbed for the north, the quotation improving l½ to 103. Great Westerns advanced 1 1/4, South Westerns Deferred 1. and Midland Preferred and North Western ¾ Metropolitans on Wednesday gained 1 ½ despite the traffic decrease of £1,579, but yesterday no change in the price was recorded. To-day the tone has not been so firm, South Westerns Deferred have been an exception, and have advanced 1 ½ In several oases there are losses of ¼
Americans

The recovery in Wall Street after the excitement and subsequent relapse following the Governorship election has been signalised by a firmer tone here in American shares, and quite an active business has been done. There has been a strong demand for Milwaukees which have advanced by leaps and bounds. and up to last night the quotation was 14 points higher than last Friday's close. They leave off to night at 188 1/7. Unions also have been greatly in favour. and yesterday attained 190 7/8. closing 2 1/8 to the good at 190 ½. Southern Pacifics were also a good market, and Louisville received substantial support.
This market has been somewhat irregular. To day. Unions are 7/8 lower at 189 3/8, but Southern Pacifies have gained 1/4 at 97 7/8.
Egyptians.

After the state of idleness prevailing in the Egyptian market last week, the revival noticeable this week has been very welcome. Quite a

good business has been done in Egyptian shares, and prices are mostly higher on balance. Khedivial Mail have continued in strong demand, and have changed hands as high as 2 3/16. but close a little off the top at 2 1/8. Land and General Trust have also been largely dealt in, the price being rather higher at 4s. 6d. premium. Delta Land and Investment have been bought up to 4¾ dosing easier to night at 4 3/8 doubtful.

Following a long spell of inactivity, Delta Preference Bearer are again being enquired after, aha are a fraction better at 12 ¼. National Bank of Egypt are better at 27 3/8, as also are Agricultural Banks at 9 7/8 buyers. Agricultural Bank Preference are quoted 9 ¾, the Debentures being flat at 89 ½. Union Fonciere have risen slightly to 6, 9/16 bid, and seem a firm market, but there is very little doing in them. Corporation of Western Egypt have been bought at 9/32 premium, and then at 11/32 premium, the last price being 5/16 premium. New Egyptian at 1 11/16 and Land Bank at 9 are unchanged. Daira Sanieh were dull during the first part of the week, falling to 17 sellers, but buyers have come forward, and the price to-night is 17 ¼ bid. The Deferred are not mentioned. Egyptian Estates are up to 2 7/15 but the declaration of the dividend has not had much effect on the market. The Deferred are 16-17 nominal.

Salt and Soda are closing 26s6d buyers, and they are supposed to have been dealt in at 27s. Egyptian Markets at 1 3/8 are unmentioned. The important information received from Egypt of the opening of a large number of the dosed markets does not seem to be appreciated here, but as soon as it is there will no doubt be a considerable rise in these shares. Daira Sugar at 2 5/8 are also steady, but Bank of Roumania are a bad market at 9 1/2 sellers.
Mining.

The South African market is suffering from lack of support. The leading Rand shares continue to show a sagging tendency as moat of the big houses are refraining from giving assistance pending a dearer understanding of the political future of South Africa.

Kaffirs have been very weak but are closing' rather better, Rand Mines having put on 1/16 at 6 1/16 There has again been considerable movement in Vaal River shares, but these have weakened to-day, and are 1/8 lower at 8 1/4. De Beers are favoured on Paris account at 21 ½. The dividend on the Deferred is due in December, and the market is anticipating 15s. against 10s. in June.
In the Rhodesian section Taoganyikas have hardened to 5 ¼, a rise to day of 3/16.

In the market for Egyptian mining shares, Egyptian Options have shown a certain amount of activity, and the price has been up to 1 3/8, but close at 5/15 Egyptian Mines are also better at 4/6, but Nile Valley are easier at 4/-.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report
Liverpool, November 15.

Spinners still continue to buy very sparingly, and with some pressure to sell prices are very irregular. The following changes have been made in quotations:—Fair Brown is 1/8 dearer, Good Fair is unchanged, whilst Folly Good Fair to Fine Brown are 1/8 dearer. Good Fair and Folly Good Fair Uppers are 1/16 down, other qualities are unchanged. In Futures a fair business has been done, and the latest values are, delivery: —
Nov. 9.14d Febr. 8.59 May 8.59
Deo. 9.3 Mar. 8.59 Jane 8.59
Jan. 8.60 April 8.59

American Futures— The market this week has fluctuated violently. Prices fell 17 points below those of last week, recovered about 30 points, and at to-day's close are 8 @ 12 points above those of last Thursday. The chief feature is the extreme sensitiveness of the market, consequently it is easily manipulated, and there has been plenty of it, as shown by the daily sharp fluctuations. Big crop movements, although somewhat less than a week ago; big crop estimates, which seem to us lacking in justification; and an impression that, the Bureau Ginners' report, due next Wednesday, will mark an increase, have all had their effect, and been made the most of. The weather the last two or three days has again been extremely unfavourable: killing frost in many sections, and low temperatures generally throughout the belt, followed by heavy rains, and in some districts snow, must lessen the possibility of a yield from the top crop.

The following are the latest quotations :— Nov. 5.49 ½ Jan./Feb. 5.40 ½ Apl./May 5.47 Nov./Dec. 5.43 ½ Feb /Mar 5.42 ½ May/June 5.49 ½ Dec./Jan 5.41 Mar./Apl. 5.44 ½ June/July 5.51 ½ July/Aug.5.51 ½ Aug./Sept. 5.47.
PS.—The bye-law with regard to the closing of this market at 4 30 p.m. having been rescinded, the market now closes at 4 p.m. on every day except Saturday, when it doses at 12.30 p.m.
